723048f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East - Chrystie Street
723048f-b.text:
Roosevelt (Sarah Delano) Park: A set of 4 views of the clearance
between Chrystie (left) and Forsyth (rdght) Streets, northward from
several different points, to East Houston Street,which will be improved
as a play area and dedicated to the mother of President Franklin D.
Roosevelt. These Views are progressively from Hester (No. 1), Grand
(No. 2), Delancey (No. 3) and Rivington Streets. Nos. 1 and 2 shows
the Libby Hotel standing on the north side of Melancey Street and about
to be razed.
October 7, 1930.
Views 1, 2 \& 3.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
723048f-b.folder: Houston Street (East & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

719482f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719482f-a.text:
138 to 142 (left to right) East Houston Street, north side, east of
Second Ave., as seen when viewed northward on Forsyth Street. The entire
bbock of houses of Mhich these were a part, were demolished to facilitate
the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. Subway).
The site is now a public playground. On the extreme left appears build-
ings at the S.W. corner of East Houston,and Forsyth Streets, which today
(1937) are gone; the same being a portion of the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Park.
July 13, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719481f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719481f-a.text:
128 East Houston Street, east of the N.E. corner of Second Ave.,
showing the store-front of a 6-story tenement house. This building, together
with the others comprising the block between Second and First Aves., were
later rased to make way for the construction of the IIndependent System
Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719477f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Chrystie Street
719477f-b.text:
109 to 95 East Houston Street, south side, west from but not
including (left, not shown) Chrystie Street, to the Bowery, showing
St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish) at Nos. 109-105, and the 11-
story Fisher Building (Wos. 103-97). Also shown, at the N.W. corner
of Second Ave., is construction work in progress on the Independent
System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway) after demolition of the houses which
formerly occupied the site. St. Augustine's Chapel was erected in
1876 and is considered to be a striking architectural feature of New
York. It has two parts, a mission house and the church proper. The
mission house contains a large hall, guild and school-rooms. The work
is almoat entirely among the poorer classes of the neighborhood and
includes social activities of a varied nature.
June 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719477f-b.folder: Houston Street (East) & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

719477f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Chrystie Street

719477f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

718847f-a.title: Manhattan: Chrystie Street - Houston Street (East)
718847f-a.text:
Chrystie Street, west side, south from East Houston, to Canal Streets,
as seen from East Houston Street, and across clearance durinr the construction
of the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Park.
March 16, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
718847f-a.folder: Chrystie Street & Houston Street (East), Manhattan, NY

732816f-a.title: Recreation - Billiards.
732816f-a.text:
Recreation--billiards: Teh entrance to a pocket billiards place
on Second Avenue near E. Houston Street, Manhattan. Note the
warning on the doorway: ''No Minors Allowed; 'o Prunks AllowedT

707747f-a.text:
.W. corner of Second Avenue and East Houston Street.  July 17, 1929.
.1. Sperr,Photographer.

707747f-a.folder: 2nd Ave. & Houston St. E., Manhattan, NY

719468f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719468f-b.text:
(1)
East Houston Street, west from but not including the Bowery, as
seen from the Fisher Building (No. 97-103 East Houston Street, between
the Bowery and Chrystie Street). Also shown is a general view of the
surrounding area. The buildings on the north side of the street, to the
depth of 100 feet were raed to make way for the construction of the
Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). The buildings in the
foreground, of which only the upper stories are visible are on the west
side of the Bowery.
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A portion of the view shown in No. 1 (north side) at a later date,
as seen from the Houston Street Station of the Third Ave. Elevated
Line, on the Bowery, and showing an exclusive view of Houston Street.
Note the clearance between Elisabeth and Mott Streets after the houses
which occupied that site were rared. The other buildings were demolished
later.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS. ..
(3)
A portion of the view shown in No. 1. Also shown (right) are
Nos. 286 to 310 Bowery, west side, north from East Houston, to but not
including Bleecker Street. IIn the foreground appears a portion of the
Houston Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719480f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719480f-a.text:
120-122 (left), und 124-106 East Houston Street, at and adjoining the
N.E. corner of Second Ave., showing the store-fronts of two 5-story build-
ings. The entire block of houses of which these are a bart were later
demolished to make way for the construction of the Independent System
Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). On their site is now (1937) a playground
and park.
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719471f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719471f-a.text:
East Houston Street, east from but not including the Bowery, showing
construction work in progress (on the north side of the street), on the
Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway), after the buildings
which previously had occupied that area, were razed. In the background is
visible a portion of the Second Ave. Elevated Line, running at this point
on First Ave.
October 12, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

East Houston Street, west from but not including the Bowery, as

September 19, 1929.

NO REPRODUCTIONS. ..

Nos. 286 to 310 Bowery, west side, north from East Houston, to but not

July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719478f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Chrystie Street
719478f-a.text:
111-117 East Houston Street, at the S.W. corner of Chrystie Street
(the foot of Second Ave.), showing the National (formerly known as the
Thomashefsky)Theatre, a Jewish leeitimate stage playhouse, as seen from
a point on Second Ave. Aiso shown (indistinctly) is Chrystie Street,
west side, south from and inclu..ing East Houston Street. On the right
is visible a portion of St. Augustine's Chapel (1O5-109 East Houston Street).
June 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719478f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

719473f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719473f-a.text:
East Houston Street, at the N.E. corner of Second Ave., and showing
the rears of buildings on the south side of East 1st Street, across clearance
occasioned by the new Eighth Ave. Subway link.
October 28, 1936.
P. L. Snerr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719504f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719504f-b.text:
(1)
252-256 East Houston Street, north side, between Avemue A
and B, as seen from Norfolk Street.
May 8, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing a further view east to and including No. 264
East Houston Street. 262 and 264 are 4-story frame houses with
brick fronts.
April 8, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719504f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719504f-a.text:
(1)
252-256 East Houston Street, north side, between Avemue A
and B, as seen from Norfolk Street.
May 8, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing a further view east to and including No. 264
East Houston Street. 262 and 264 are 4-story frame houses with

April 8, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719472f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719472f-a.text:
East Houston Street, north side, at the foot of Second Ave. (where
bus is parked), as seen from the foot of Forsyth Street, looking north-
westward. The clearance shown was created as a result of the demolition
of houses which formerly stood there, to make way for the construction
of the Independent System Subway (Eihth Ave. subway).
March 13, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

707751f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - Houston St. E.
707751f-a.text:
9 Second Avenue, between Houston and 1st -treets, west side; ''Germaina
Flats''. Church of All Nations is in first floor right.
January 16, 1931.
P.L. iperr,Photographer.
NO RES..ODUCTION.
707751f-a.folder: 2nd Ave. & Houston St. E., Manhattan, NY

719474f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719474f-a.text:
East Houston Street, north side, east from but not including Second
Ave., showing construction work on the Independent System Subway (Eighth
Ave. Subway) after the houses which stood on this site were razed. This
area was later transformed into a playground. On the extreme left are
seen the rears of buildings facing on East lst Street, between Second
and First Aves. Also shown (background) is the 1st Street station of the
Second Ave. Elevated Line, running at this point on First Ave.
May 9, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719470f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - 2nd Avenue
719470f-a.text:
East Houston Street, at the N.E. corner of the Bowery, showing the
clearance created bv the demolition of the houses which occupied that
site. The buildings shown (plus a 1, and 5-story annexes) are facing
on the Bowery. Also shown (extreme left) is a portion of the Third Ave.
Elevated line on the Bowery. This area between Second and Third Aves.
is today (1937) an automobile parking lot.
March 13, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719476f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Chrystie Street
719476f-a.text:
(1)
105-109 East Houston Street, south side, between the Bowery and  Chrystie Street, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish). It ]  is one of the striking architectural features of the city and is a
Chapel of Old Trinity, erected in 1876. IIt has two main parts, a
mission house and the church proper. The five floors of the mission 1
house contain a large hall, school, guild-rooms and a parish room.
The work is almost entirely among the indigent classes of the neighborhood.i
Besides a Sunday-school, it has a day school for boys and a night school
for both men and women; giving instruction in sewing and cooking.
March 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A portion of the same, showing the rear of the belfry as seen from
the Fisher Building (adjoining the church). Also shown is a general
view, northward, of the neighboring area, with Second Ave. seen on the
left.
July 17, 1929.
719476f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Chrystie Street, Manhattan, NY

Chapel of Old Trinity, erected in 1876. IIt has two main parts, a
mission house and the church proper. The five floors of the mission 1

The work is almost entirely among the indigent classes of the neighborhood.i
Besides a Sunday-school, it has a day school for boys and a night school

NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)

the Fisher Building (adjoining the church). Also shown is a general
view, northward, of the neighboring area, with Second Ave. seen on the
left.
July 17, 1929.

707748f-a.title: Manhattan: 2nd Ave. - Houston St. E.
707748f-a.text:
Second Avenue, north from East Houston Street, showing
nain East Side thorouohfare at its inception.
July 1928.
L. Balgue,
T LINE IMPERATIVE.
707748f-a.folder: 2nd Ave. & Houston St. E., Manhattan, NY

732865f-a.text:
(1)
''Bocci' (Italian bowling) is still played by Italian Americans.
View at East Houston and Chrystie Streets.
May 8, 1934.
L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Neg. 4271o
(2)
The same; a more distant view.
May 8, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
